thread.title: Using seawater and crisp packets to cut CO2 emissions

title: Using seawater and crisp packets to cut CO2 emissions
text:
Using seawater and crisp packets to cut CO2 emissions 5:44am EST - 02:08 
University of York scientists say 850 million tonnes of carbon dioxide could be mineralised each year by combining sea water, graphite, solar-powered electricity, and scrap metal in a purpose-built reactor. Jim Drury reports.   
University of York scientists say 850 million tonnes of carbon dioxide could be mineralised each year by combining sea water, graphite, solar-powered electricity, and scrap metal in a purpose-built reactor. Jim Drury reports.  //reut.rs/2sqKuF3
